+Ahmed Mohamed Conservative means to be restrictive in allowances 
and privileges when dealing with morality, social norms, cultural values, 
issues regarding religion, faith, freedoms concerning access to 
religion(s), as well as policies dealing with personal expressionism 
through individuality. (such as tattoos, body piercings, clothing and hair 
styles, artistic expression, music, media, as well as social interactions, 
and whom one chooses to associate with)
Example 1.) Allowing a woman to wear what she wants in public would be 
described as liberal. Placing rules on what a woman can wear in public 
(within reason, obviously nudity is commonly unacceptable), and having 
policies requiring a specific state of dress (such as requiring people to 
wear clothing that provides a specified level of coverage), would be 
described as conservative.
Example 2.) Extending and protecting rights and privileges to people within 
a given society who do not share in the most common or popular morals and 
values would be described as liberal. Restricting rights and privileges of 
people within a given society who do not share in the most common or 
popular morals and values would be described as conservative.
Example 3.) Demonstrating an acceptance towards change and allowing for 
differing views, as well as social and cultural differences to co-exist 
would be described as liberal. Demonstrating resistance to change, and 
restricting or discouraging differing views, as well as social and cultural 
differences and preventing them from co-existing, or simply restriction the 
amount of interaction between people who share differing views, values, and 
cultural differences would be described as conservative.
Example 4.) Freedom of Religion and Freedom of Speech are liberal concepts. 
Restrictions on what religious beliefs may be practiced within a given 
society including restrictive provisions on what is allowed in public 
regarding speech and the expression of one's own opinions are conservative 
concepts.
There are numerous examples of Conservative views and values. What one 
culture or society would consider as conservative, another culture or 
society would consider normal or even liberal. And what one culture or 
society would consider as liberal, another culture or society would 
consider it as conservative. Thus depending on what sort of society or 
culture you live in is going to determine what you may consider as liberal 
or conservative. I, for example might consider myself to be somewhat 
conservative with moderate leanings. While someone else would see me as 
radically liberal or even extremely leftwing. And yet in another person 
would see me as radically conservative or even extremely rightwing. It's 
all a matter of perspective. For example: What is your definition of 
"conservative"?

"Religion held back Science"
"Religion oppressed Women"

Both are demonstrably false and actually it is the complete opposite. 
Religion advanced scientific studies, religion advanced the rights of women.

Just two quotes to prove the above as falsehoods:

"Although popular images of controversy continue to exemplify the supposed 
hostility of Christianity to new scientific theories, studies have shown 
that Christianity has often nurtured and encouraged scientific endeavour, 
while at other times the two have co-existed without either tension or 
attempts at harmonization. If Galileo and the Scopes trial come to mind as 
examples of conflict, they were the exceptions rather than the rule."

"According to Professor William Montgomery Watt, when seen in such 
historical context, Muhammad "can be seen as a figure who testified on 
behalf of women's rights." The general improvement of the status of Arab 
women included prohibition of female infanticide and recognizing women's 
full personhood. Women generally gained greater rights than women in 
pre-Islamic Arabia and medieval Europe. Women were not accorded with such 
legal status in other cultures until centuries later."

So next time you lot open your mouth read a history book first. ﻿

+shocco It doesn't matter how people *interpret* religion. Look, anyone can 
claim their particular sect of Islam/Christianity/Judaism is the *only* 
true interpretation of the religion, but in reality every religious

Islam to be whatever you want.

What matters is this: Religion, regardless of the particular 
interpretation, and regardless of whether or not you agree with the 
particular interpretation, is *overall* a force for evil.

The Saudis that practice what you believe to be an incorrect interpretation 
of Islam are *still practicing a religion*; they still worship a god. They 
are acting in accordance to what they believe Islam teaches. That's the 
important part.

planet. They literally require you to convert to Islam before you become a

http://www.moi.gov.sa/wps/wcm/connect/121c03004d4bb7c98e2cdfbed7ca8368/EN_saudi_nationality_system.pdf?MOD=AJPERES&CACHEID=121c03004d4bb7c98e2cdfbed7ca8368

But again, I don't know how you can claim religion is a force for good when 
nearly every anti-science and anti-woman movement has been religion-based. 
It's easy to look at a society which is mostly religious, see that it is 
advancing women's rights, and attribute that advance to religion. But that 
necessarily isn't the case.

Look, I'm not arguing religion is entirely anti-science. After all, where 
would we be if it were not for the Christian-inspired surge of rationality 
during the Renaissance, or the 900-1200 A.D. Golden Age of Muslim science? 
What I *am* arguing, however, is that religion is mostly anti-science, and 
anti-progress in general.

And yes, modern conditions do serve as evidence for this. We can clearly 
trace the history of each country and determine the average level of 
religiosity over the course of human history. What we find is that there 
exists a large progress gap, both socially and technologically, between 
religious countries and non-religious countries. You can't simply sweep 
this under a rug.

Finally, Christianity isn't limited to the teachings of Jesus. The Earth 
being created before light, humans living hundreds of years, millions of 
animals boarding a single ship... I wouldn't exactly call these passages 
scientific, would you? And before you pull the *the old testament doesn't 
count* argument, remember that the New Testament is merely an extension of 
the Old Testament. As Jesus himself says, "do not think that I have come to 
abolish the law or the prophets.  I have come not to abolish but to 
fulfill" (Matthew 5:17).

+glassplotful "You keep bringing up these instances where the Muslim world 
is fighting for women's rights, as if that is evidence that religion is 
pro-women." 

Instances? You mean a gigantic shift in cultural thinking, law, rights, 
science and medicine that resulted in hundreds of years of advancement. If 
that's not evidence religion is pro women then what is? Before religion = 
no rights for women, After religion = much greater rights for women. Can 
you see what factor changed rights for women? Why are you downplaying the 
role of religion on society. Can't you accept religion had a catalysing 
effect on rights as fact?

"But what you have failed to mention is that, generally speaking, countries 
that are more secular overwhelmingly support gender equality, whereas 
countries that are less secular are just now starting to allow women the 
same basic rights as men."

Your problem is your only looking at modern history rather than human 
history. If you looked at human history what you'll see is religion has 
largely played a driving force in science and women's rights. It may not be 
the case now but you have to ask yourself why that is? Why are these 
societies are less liberal now than in the Middle Ages? Is it because 
religion has suddenly changed it's message? Or is it that vested interests 
have no ambition to follow religious law as it says and simply pick and 
choose what suits them. If this is the case you then must ask yourself is 
this a fault with religion or the persons implementing religious laws?

You make the case of Saudi Arabia. If you were aware of Saudi history you 
would know the Wahaabism that Saudi law is based on NOT Shariah came as a 
result of a sect of extremely conservative tribe called the Wahabbis and 
their teachings are a DIRECT contradiction to the teachings of the Quran. 
There is nothing Islamic about Saudi Arabia today. So don't bring up the 
Taliban or Saudi Arabia as evidence of anything Islamic.

My argument has never been secular movements have stifled women's rights or 
science. My argument has simply been that religion has played a positive 
role in the rights of women contrary to the original poster so I reject 
bring up an example of anything secular movements have or haven't done.

And you make claim christianity is not pro science? Are you talking about 
the teachings of the Gospel or those that 'practice' the religion itself? 
They are two different things. i haven't read the gospel but I can't 
foresee any teachings of Jesus that prevent or subdue scientific research.

You don't even need to examine history to know what you are saying is dead 
wrong.

You keep bringing up these instances where the Muslim world is fighting for 
women's rights, as if that is evidence that religion is pro-women. But what 
you have failed to mention is that, generally speaking, countries that are *more 
secular* overwhelmingly support gender equality, whereas countries that are *less 
secular* are *just now* starting to allow women the same basic rights as 
men. Need I remind you that women are still banned from driving in Saudi 
Arabia?

You are correct in stating that Christianity has supported science, but 
overwhelming it has had a record of being anti-science. Nearly every 
anti-science movement in western history has its roots in religion, and if 
you believe otherwise, *point me to a secular movement that opposed science* 
in western history.

The opposition to evolution, geology, and geography is *entirely* 
religion-based. The ones who are trying to insert pseudo-science into the 
public classroom are the religious. There are even Christians attempting to 
re-write the definition of science such that the scientific method would be 
bypassed and Creationism could be taught as sound science. Christianity is 
*NOT* pro-science.

+JabberCT  I think we have a small misunderstanding because you first say 
"They are definitely exclusive" And then you say "I am a Agnostic Atheist" 
That is my point, Agnostic and atheist are NOT exclusive to one another you 
can be BOTH at the same time.

"any religious person with faith is also a agnostic." But definition this 
is not true. If you have faith in a deity you can not be agnostic. Someone 
that is agnostic does not know if there is a god or not AKA lack of faith 
in a deity. Having faith in a deity and being a agnostic contradict 
themselves.

"If a person does not actively worship a God, then they are a Atheist"

If you believe in ANY deity you are not a Atheist. If you believe for 
example allah exists but you do not actively worship him that does not make 
you a atheist.

They have very basic definitions:

Atheist: Lack of a belief in a deity

Agnostic: A person who does not know if a deity exists or not and does not 
feel they have enough evidence to say a deity does not exist or not 100%

Can I say a deity does not 100% absolutely exist? No. Do I believe a deity 
exists? No. <----- Agnostic Atheist.

+JabberCT Exactly.  They are 2 different words used for 2 different things.

Magic, miracles, ghosts, or anything supernatural does not exist, so I feel

I don't have any solid evidence for my statement.  So I don't expect others

As the Ottoman Empire entered a permanent phase of decline in the late 17th 
century it was engaged in a protracted state of conflict, losing 
territories both in Europe and the Caucasus. The victors were the Christian 
States, the old Habsburg and Romanov Empires and the new nation-states of 
Greece, Serbia, Romania and Bulgaria.[55] Rival European powers encouraged 
the development of nationalist ideologies among the Ottoman subjects in 
which the Muslims were portrayed as an ethnic “fifth column” leftover from 
a previous era that could not be integrated into the planned future states. 
The struggle to rid themselves of Ottomans became an important element of 
the self-identification of the Balkan Christians.[56]

According to Mark Levene, the Victorian public in the 1870s paid much more 
attention to the massacres and expulsions of Christians than to massacres 
and expulsions of Muslims, even if on a greater scale. He further suggests 
that such massacres were even favored by some circles. Mark Levene also 
argues that the dominant powers, by supporting "nation-statism" at the 
Congress of Berlin, legitimized "the primary instrument of Balkan 
nation-building": ethnic cleansing.[57] Hall points out that atrocities 
were committed by all sides during the Balkan conflicts. Deliberate terror 
was designed to instigate population movements out of particular 
territories. The aim of targeting the civilian population was to carve 
ethnically homogeneous countries.[58]

During the Russo-Turkish War of 1787–1792 the Russian Army commander 
Alexander Suvorov successfully besieged the fortress of Izmail on December 
22, 1790. Ottoman forces inside the fortress had the orders to stand their 
ground to the end, haughtily declining the Russian ultimatum. Alexander 
Suvorov announced the capture of Ismail in 1791 to the Tsarina Catherine in 
a doggerel couplet, after the assault had been pressed from house to house, 
room to room, and nearly every Muslim man, woman, and child in the city had 
been killed in three days of uncontrolled massacre, 40,000 Turks dead, a 
few hundred taken into captivity. For all his bluffness, Suvorov later told 
an English traveller that when the massacre was over he went back to his 
tent and wept.[59]

Justin McCarty estimates that between 1821 and 1922 around five and a half 
million Muslims were driven out of Europe and five million more were killed 
or died of disease and starvation while fleeing.[60] Cleansing occurred as 
a result of the Serbian and Greek independence in the 1820s and 1830s, the 
Russo-Turkish War 1877–1878, and culminating in the Balkan Wars 1912–1913. 
Mann describes these acts as “murderous ethnic cleansing on stupendous 
scale not previously seen in Europe” referring to the 1914 Carnegie 
Endowment report.[61][62] It is estimated that at the turn of the 20th 
century there were 4,4 million Muslims living in the Balkan zone of Ottoman 
control.[63] More than one million Muslims left the Balkans in the last 
three decades of the 19th century.[64] Between 1912 and 1926 nearly 2.9 
million Muslims were either killed or forced to emigrate to Turkey.[63]

Between 10,000[65] and 30,000[66][67][68] Turks were killed in Tripolitsa 
by Greek rebels in the summer of 1821, including the entire Jewish 
population of the city. Similar events as these occurred also elsewhere 
during the Greek Revolution resulting in the eradication and expulsion of 
virtually the entire Turkish population of the Morea. These acts ensured 
the ethnic homogenization of the area under the rule of the future modern 
Greek state.[69] In 1830 the Muslims population in Morea is put at 300,000. 
In 1878 the Muslim inhabitants in Thessaly are estimated to be 150,000 and 
in 1897 the Muslims numbered 50,000 in Crete. By 1919 there were virtually 
no Muslims left in Morea and Thessaly and only 20,000 in Crete.[70]

In the Bulgarian insurgency of the April Uprising in 1876 an estimate of 
1,000 Muslims were killed.[71][72] During the Russo-Turkish War a 
significant number of Turks were either killed, perished or became 
refugees. There are different estimates about the casualties of the war. 
Crampton describes an exodus of 130,000-150,000 expelled of which 
approximately half returned for an intermediary period encouraged by the 
Congress of Berlin. Hupchick and McCarthy point out that 260,000 perished 
and 500,000 became refugees.[73][74] The Turkish scholars Karpat and Ipek 
argue that up to 300,000 were killed and 1–1.5 million were forced to 
emigrate.[75][76] Members of the European press who covered the war in 
Bulgaria reported on the Russian atrocities against Muslims. Witness 
accounts from Schumla and Razgrad describe children, women and elderly 
wounded by sabres and lances. They stated that the entire Muslim population 
of many villages had been massacred.[77] Recently uncovered photographs in 
the archive of the German Ministry of Foreign Affairs from the 
Russo-Turkish War 1877–1878 show the massacre of Muslims by the Russians in 
the region of Stara Zagora claiming to have affected some 20,000 Muslim 
civilians.[78]

Massacres against Turks and Muslims during the Balkan Wars in the hands of 
Bulgarians, Greeks and Armenians are described in detail in the 1912 
Carnegie Endowment report.[79] The Bulgarian violence during the Balkan War 
included burning of villages, transforming mosques into churches, rape of 
women and mutilation of bodies. It is estimated that 220,000 Pomaks were 
forcefully Christianized and forbidden to bear Islamic religious clothing

The Lipka Tatars, also known as Polish Tatars or Lithuanian Tatars, were a 
community of Tatar Muslims who migrated into the Grand Duchy of Lithuania 
and became Polonized

The Counter-Reformation of the Catholic Church in the Grand Duchy led to 
persecution of Muslims, Jews, and Orthodox Christians, among the measures 
taken were banning the repair of old Mosques and preventing new ones from 
being constructed, banning serfdom of Christians under Muslims, banning 
marriage of Christian females to Muslims, putting limitations on property 
ownership among Tatars and the Ottoman-Polish conflict fed into the 
discriminatory atmosphere against them and led to anti-Islamic writings and 
attacks.[38]

Arabs relying largely on Berbers conquered the Iberian Peninsula starting 
in 711, subduing the whole Visigothic Kingdom by 725. The triumphant 
Umayyads got conditional capitulations probably in most of the towns, so 
that they could get a compromise with the native population. This was not 
always so. For example, Mérida, Cordova, Toledo, or Narbonne were conquered 
by storm or after laying siege on them. The arrangement reached with the 
locals was based on respecting the laws and traditions used in each place, 
so that the Goths (a legal concept, not an ethnic one, i.e. the communities 
ruled by the Forum Iudicum) continued to be ruled on new conditions by 
their own tribunals and laws.[28] The Gothic Church remained in place and 
collaborated with the new masters. Al-Andalus or Muslim ruled Iberian 
peninsula, was conquered by northern Christian kingdoms in 1492, as a 
result of their expansion taking place especially after the definite 
collapse of the Caliphate of Cordova in 1031.

The coming of the Crusades (starting with the massacre of Barbastro) and 
similarly entrenched positions on the northern African Almoravids, who took 
over al-Andalus as of 1086, added to the difficult coexistence between 
communities, including Muslims in Christian ruled territory, or the 
Mozarabic rite Christians (quite different from those of the northern 
kingdoms), and further minority groups. The Almohads, a fanatic north 
African sect, pushed the boundaries of religious intolerance during their 
occupation of al-Andalus, affecting also the Jews.[29]

During the expansion south of the northern Christian kingdoms, depending on 
the local capitulations, local Muslims were allowed to remain (Mudéjars) 
with some restrictions, while some were assimilated into the Christian 
faith. After the conquest of Granada, all the Spanish Muslims were under 
Christian rule. The new acquired population spoke Arabic or Mozarabic, and 
the campaigns to convert them were unsuccessful. Legislation was gradually 
introduced to remove Islam, culminating with the Muslims being forced to 
convert to Catholicism by the Spanish Inquisition. They were known as 
Moriscos and considered New Christians. Further laws were introduced, as on 
25 May 1566, stipulating that they 'had to abandon the use of Arabic, 
change their costumes, that their doors must remain open every Friday, and 
other feast days, and that their baths, public and private, to be torn 
down.'[30] The reason doors were to be left open so as to determine whether 
they secretly observed any Islamic festivals.[31] King Philip II of Spain 
ordered the destruction of all public baths on the grounds of them being 
relics of infidelity, notorious for their use by Muslims performing their 
purification rites.[32][33] The possession of books or papers in Arabic was 
near concrete proof of disobedience with severe repercussions.[34] On 1 
January 1568, Christian priests were ordered to take all Morisco children 
between the ages of three and fifteen, and place them in schools, where 
they should learn Castillian and Christian doctrine.[35] All these laws and 
measures required force to be implemented, and from much earlier.

Between 1609 and 1614 the Moriscos were expelled from Spain.[36] They were 
to depart 'under the pain of death and confiscation, without trial or 
sentence... to take with them no money, bullion, jewels or bills of 
exchange... just what they could carry.'[37]

I'm half Algerian and I've been traveling around the region since birth. 
The village my family is from in Kabylia (a berber region in Algeria) is 
pretty secular; people drink wine (and beer), eat boar and the mosque is 
always empty. Two years ago, aged 19, I desperately wanted to take a day 
trip to a historic roman city in a slightly more religious part of the 
region. My grandmother asked my 23 year old male cousin to go with me 'just 
in case'. I was quite naive, I just thought he was there to drive me 
around. But now I understand that it had nothing to do with having a 
chauffeur: I was catcalled and groped at the hips, waist and backside. My 
cousin assured me to just keep my head down and to not look at them...it 
was so alien to me, having been raised in France, I've always been told to 
stand up for myself. My cousin was amazing that day, he did something I 
wasn't able to do: he stood up for me. I was told by a policeman to put a 
headscarf if I didn't want that kind of attention which enraged my cousin 
and we ended up going home. I went back a week later with my father and I 
was left alone even though I was wearing shorts and a t-shirt rather than 
jeans and a sweatshirt like last time.
Many women get pestered on a regular basis in those countries - it's a sad 
reality that is often accepted or taken jokingly. I'm not the kind of 
person to over-dramatize, but there is something soul-crashing to be 
continuously fighting off wandering hands or dealing with constant 
catcalling. Technically in Algeria, you have the choice to wear not not 
wear a headscarf, but often, if you want to get on with your day without 
feeling dirty, you just *have* to give in. I know many women who wear the 
headscarf not by choice, but by necessity.﻿

As someone studying human psychology, behavior and body language, I admit I 
find full face covering, even just covering everything but the eyes (but 
the full covering is worse ofc), quite disturbing. So much is communicated 
via face expression that in terms of social interaction and social 
engagement, is it like those women might as well be in a different room, 
talking through the walls if they talk at all - and sadly that may be the 
point of those garments from a psychological outside perspective.

Face expression goes a long way to influence social interaction, which way 
interaction is going, what the other person is feeling, and weather or not 
to initiate social interaction in the first place. There is a complex 
automatic series of signals displayed on the face, many of which are hidden 
by these coverings (full face one in particular as a lot of signaling 
happens around the eyes, but the mouth and jaw is still need for a full 
picture), that largely determines weather two people will engage in 
friendly interaction (such as bantering with a fellow shopper at the 
market) or weather people will ignore or avoid each other. The dark side of 
this is it can also warn us weather someone is potentially hostile or not, 
particularly when they are about to attack. Hiding all that is what I find 
disturbing. It is a communicative and social aura of the unknown that makes 
them perpetual social outsiders, always "in another room talking through 
the walls". To be blunt, without those signals, from an instinctive emotive 
perspective, it is hard to say weather she is friendly, neutral or about to 
stab you. 

Head coverings of any kind that do not hide the face on the other hand, I 
have no problem with at all, just like how I am unconcerned with how people 
style their hair.﻿

In addition, the Greek geographer Strabo, writing in the first century AD, 
refers to some Persian women veiling their faces;[9][not in citation given] 
and the early third-century Christian writer Tertullian clearly refers in 
his treatise The Veiling of Virgins to some pagan women of "Arabia" wearing 
a veil that covers not only their head but also the entire face.[10] 
Clement of Alexandria commends the contemporary use of face coverings. 
[11][12] There are also two Biblical references to the employment of 
covering face veils in Genesis 38.14 and Genesis 24.65, by Tamar and by 
Rebekah, Jacob and Abraham's daughters-in-law respectively. These primary 
sources show that some women in Egypt, Arabia, Canaan and Persia veiled 
their faces long before Islam. Some interpretations say that a veil is not 
compulsory in front of blind, asexual or gay men. 

Sheikh Muhammad Sayyid Tantawy, previous dean of Cairo's Al-Azhar 
University, called full-face veiling a custom that has nothing to do with 
the Islamic faith. “The niqab is a cultural tradition and has nothing to do 
with Islam.”[35] The decision came from an incident in which he forced a 
school girl to remove her niqab during a visit to an Al-Azhar school, when 
Tantawy reportedly said that he would call for an official ban for the face 
veil in Islamic schools. Tantawy's decision stems from his views that more 
younger Muslims have lost touch with traditional Islamic scholarship and 
have come under the influence of extremist imams who have little or no 
formal training in Islamic scholarship, despite some of the most 
influential islamic scholars holding the position that the niqab is from 
islam. Islamic Sharia law, according to certain public pundits (e.g., Mudar
